DOC.HEAD: Finance Minister Denies Reports That Japan To Raise Discount Rate
Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with finance minister disputing the reports. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `The official ... .'
DOC.TEXT: Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto denied news reports Tuesday that Japan's central bank will raise its official discount rate by 0.5 percentage point to 4.25 percent later this week. Speaking at a news conference, Hashimoto said Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno told him Tuesday morning that he knew nothing about the news reports when the two met at a monthly meeting of economy-related Cabinet ministers earlier in the day. The Yomiuri Shinbun and the Asahi Shinbun, the nation's two largest newspapers, quoting unidentified sources, reported the central bank is making final adjustments with the Finance Ministry on the rate hike, which they said will be put into effect this week. If the bank action is taken, it will be the third such discount rate hike in Japan this year. Hashimoto said Mieno gave no indication of a plan to boost the discount rate during the meeting. The minister said the domestic economic situation does not demand a third increase in the discount rate this year because prices are stable, even though exchange rate levels require watching. After the news conference, Hashimoto told Japanese reporters that he has instructed the ministry's monetary officials not to agree to any central bank plan to raise the official discount rate if the bank came up with such a plan, Kyodo News Service said. Japan's current discount rate, after a 0.75 percentage point raise March 31 and another 0.5 percentage point hike Oct. 11, stands at 3.75 percent. A spokesman for the central bank refused to confirm or deny the reports. Mieno, who assumed the central bank's highest post Sunday, told reporters at his first news conference Monday that a strong yen is necessary for the continued expansion of Japan's domestic demand-led economy. Mieno said the nation's economic conditions are favorable, and growth should continue as long as prices remain stable. But he said the central bank must continue to keep the situation under close surveillance. The official discount rate, the rate the central bank charges on its loans to commercial banks, has a strong impact on other domestic rates. Higher rates tend to make the country's currency more attractive to investors. The newspapers said the rate hike is intended to curb inflationary pressure and to stem the continuing weakness of the yen against the dollar. A lower yen tends to make imports more expensive in Japanese market, while making Japan's products in overseas markets less expensive. The spread of rising land prices beyond Tokyo and the tightening of the labor market are also behind the measure, the reports said. The measure is also aimed at narrowing the gap in interest rates between Japan and other industrialized countries, they said.
